species.speciesName: Turritis hirsuta [TA], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 358 (1777). i. "I must beg Leave, my good Friend, to retract what I mentioned to you concerning the plant I picked up in Glostershire, for on Inspection, I perceived my mistake. I likewise examined Dr. Randolph's Specimens of Cardamine bellidifolia & found them all Turritis hirsuta, tho' He said Dr. Dillenius gave Him one of the Specimens I saw—together w' th the name—I have enclosed a Specimen of the plant I collected which you will easily know—as it is our Election Week all the fellows are up, so that I have scarce time to say how much I am obliged by the curious specimens Mr. Woods brought that I am & always shall be yr. affectionate Friend & Serv. W. Sheffield [Keeper of the Museum at Oxford]. Are you got thro' the Syngenescallass? Wor-Coll. [presumably Worcester College, Oxford] Friday afternoon" [Sheffield].

species.speciesName: Euphorbia exigua [G]. i. "I found this plant, 1773, in our Cornfields, and supposed it to be only a variety of the exigua. I am still of the same opinion. It agrees indeed pretty well with the Tishy-malus Segetum longifolius. Cat. Cant. App & Rall Syn. p.312, since it is there described as Esulae exiguae Tragi persimilis, sed major; wch last circumstance may easily be accounted for; because of the Umbella quinquefida in the one & trifida in the other. The Segetalis in Ray and the Segetalis in Linnaeus are certainly two very different Plants; and I should be glad to know, and I wish it may be in your power to inform me, whether those Specimens, wch Mr. Lyons found near Triplow, be at all different from this Specimen-another circumstance also makes me conclude that it is only a variety of the exigua; because found in company wth it, and am inclined to think that it never will be found anywhere else. I gathered more of it at the same Time; but have either mislaid or shuffled it away. But if I should find the same variety again, I will endeavour to collect the Seed of it, and try what it will do in my Garden. Supposing all other circumstances equal, the quinquefida must be to the trifida in Magnitude in the Proportion of 5 to 3, wch wants only one third part of being twice as big" [B]. ii. "Euphorbia segetalis of D. Lyons, not of Lin: It seems to be only a Variety of Euphorb: exigua Lin: In Cornfields in Norfolk, Mr. Bryant. I compared this with Lyon's own Specimen, now in the possession of Mr. Banks"

Galeopsis hirta [TA]. i. "Galeopsis hirta. Solandri. Sideritis arvensis latifolia hirsuta lutea. Ray. Syn. 242. In Corn fields near Bangor in Carnarvonshire, going from thence towards Snowdon" [JL].

Folder 1\. Galeopsis hirta [G]. i\. "Galeopsis Eboracensis - Betonica hirta Huds." [JL]. Sheet 1\. Galeopsis eboracensis [TA]; G. hirta [G]. i. Cites Ray's Syn. 242. ii. "Yellow-flower'd field Ironwort. July. This Plant grows wild in the West Riding of Yorkshire, about Wakefield, Darfield, Sheffield & c. among Corn plentifully. It belongs to Linnaeus's Genus of Galeopsis, the lower Lip of the flower having the two elevated hollow Dents, which are the Characters of that Genus, but it is taken no Notice of by that Author under that Genus or any other. Hudson falsely calls it Betonica hirta. The Plant is about a foot or eighteen Inches high, & branched; the flowers have long Tubes, are of a light yellow Colour almost white, with the inside of the lower lip mark'd with a deeper yellow. It differs from the Galeopsis Tetrahit in having no gouty Swellings at the Joints, nor long Hairs upon the Leaves & Stalks, nor acutely serrated, nor long weak Aristae to the Calyces" [JL]. iii. "Prob. Galeopsis ochraleuca or Downy Hemp Nettle" [?].

species.speciesName: Salix nova [TA]; S. arbuscula [G]. i. "These seem to be the original specimens of what Mr. Lightfoot described for Salix myrsinites (no such thing. T.A.) (he having wrote Arbuscula on the enclosed ticket by mistake) see Flora Scotica. This is not however the true myrsinites, which is what he had from Glen-co, (see other paper) but rather a new species, which Linnaeus himself seems by his herbarium to have confounded with myrisinites. Saxifraga nivalis Lin: Snowdon in Wales, & on the Mountains of Breadalbane in Scotland
Cites Linn. Vid. Fl. Lap. t. 2, f. 5, 6; Ray's Syn. 354, t. 16, f. 1.

Mountain Saxifrage. This rare plant is found on the highest Rocks of Snowdon in Carnarvonshire, & no Account of it anywhere else in Great Britain. It flowers in June. We have seen it in Scotland, on the Mountains of Breadalbane; "In Ben Weevish East Ross Scotland, T. Agnew. Also in Craig Chailleach Breadalbane Scotland. T.A."

species.speciesName: Saxifraga oppositifolia [TA]. i. Cites Linn. Sp. Pl. 402; Ray's Syn. ii. "Mountain Heath-like Sengreen, with large purple flowers. March & April. I found this upon the Rocks near the Summit of the West-side of Ingleborough Hill in Yorkshire. It grows likewise in Wales upon the Rocks of Snowdon" [JL].

folders.description: Saxifraga stellaris \[JL\]. i. Cites Linn. Sp. Pl. 400; Ray's Syn. ii. "Hairy Kidney-wort. June to September" [JL]. iii. "Snowdon" [JL]. iv. "Saxifraga stellaris. Ben Lomond. Mr. Y. [Thomas Yalden] says he found the S. nivalis there" [JL]. Carex dioica—androgynous specimens and C. capitata Huds. [G]. i. "Carex dioica. Androgynous Specimens" [B]; "which is probably what Hudson intends by his C. capitata for I never saw any other in England that came so near it. And this is certainly not the true one of Lin." [Two sheets of specimens in folder, one labelled "Carex dioica. G." [G] and "(Foemina)" [TA], the other "Carex dioica-mas. G." [G]].
Carex distans-G. [G]. i. "Carex distans? Scotland, Yalden" [JL]

Carex intermedia-singular variety-G. [G]. i. "Carex disticha with a Single Spike, w'ch approaches nearest to my Carex capitata; and not the Variety of the Carex leporina as you supposed. My C. capitata was an upright plant-the C. leporina is decumbent" [B]; "Bryant" [JL]. ii. "I cannot pronounce for certain what Spec: this is from one Sample, only, & that in its seeding State only, in so variable a Genus as the Carex. It has the Habit of a Carex, & there seems to have been 1 flower at Top y' [that] was male. Had I seen it in a younger State, I might possibly have pronounc'd w' th some certainty. Some starv'd Spec: of my C: arenar: & distica. It bids fair likewise for Hudson's C. divisa, if he has any meaning in it, but the Stalk is round" [JL]. iii. "This Carex M' Yalden found on Dorsetshire near Weymouth. He sent some Specimens of Newberry in Oxford who was inclin'd to think it no Carex, but the Schoenus fuscus. Spec: Pl: Append: 1664. It does not seem to be that for the following Reason, the Stalk is 3-quet at the Top especially, the Leaves are not filiform: but ensiforme & Micheli [Nov. plant. gen., p. 53, Ordo 1, no. 2. (1729)] says of it, Crescit apud nos cum antecedenti (viz. Sch. albo) a qua differre non vide tur nisi paniculae colore, qui prop-divisa Huds. gathered by the River Side on a dry Bank in a meadow below the Hithe at Colchester, near the Water Lock" [JL]. ii. "Colchester Hithe, an C: canescens? cant be C. aculeata for this is old. I take this to be C. loliacea Lin:" [JL].

Carex leporina Huds. nec Linnaei and C. ovalis Linn. Trans. Vol.2. G [G]. i. Cites Lin. Sp. Pl. 1381; Moris. Hist. S: 8, T: 12, f: 29; Fl: Dan: T: 294; Haller: Stirp: Helv: N° 1361. ii. "Carex leporina Lin: & Huds:" [JL]

Carex leporina Huds. and C. intermedia Linn. Trans. V.2. G. -a singular variety [G]. i. "Carex divisa? Huds. This is a variety of the former Carex, & probably is the Capitata also of Huds.---here are Spicae dioicae" [B]. ii. "Carex capitata. This is neither a Variety of C. dioica nor C. Leporina; but is undoubtedly the true C. capitata Lin.---Spica exactè ovata; nec cylindrica dioica Sp. Pl. This I believe is the only Specimen of it in Norwich---I gave it to M' Rose, when I first collected it; and I now borrowed it for your Inspection, under a Promise of Return---I went over to Brammerton, [3 miles southeast of Norwich] this season, to search again for it; but in vain---Tis so many years ago, that I have lost all Idea of the Spot where it grew, w'ch was but a small one; but it grew so thick that the Farm[er] might have mown it for a Swathe" [B].

"Hair's-Tail-Rush. This is found upon the Moors in the North of England pretty frequent, but is very rare in the southern Counties. species.speciesName: Bromus pinnatus [TA]. i. Cites Linn. Sp. Pl.; Huds. Fl. Angl.; Ray's Syn. 392. ii. "This Grass has all the characteristic Marks of a Festuca, tho' it has the Face & Habit of a Bromus. It differs from the Festuca sylvatica of Hudson only in having smooth spiculae, & very short Aristae or acumina, which do not seem to be Marks sufficiently constant to distinguish it as a Species. It is found now & then in dry stiff ground, by Roadsides & Hedges. I gathered these Samples in Glocestershire near Highnam, two Miles from Glocester in the Road to Newent, growing with the Festuca Sylvatica of Hudson. August" [JL]. iii. "Q: Bromus pinnatus Lin: in a hedge by the Alm's House. Festuca sylvat: Huds:" [JL]. iv. "Bromus pinnatus" [JL]. [Six specimens on right side of folder are all B. pinnatum; three marked "B" are var. pubescens Gray, with pubescent spikelets; three on left side are B. sylvaticum.]

1 folder. Arundo Epigeios [TA]; A. calamagrostis Linn. [G], Flora Scotica ed. 1, 106 (1777). i. "Arundo Epigeios. It was found in a green Lane or Road leading from Stoke-Newington to Southgate near London by Mr. Alchorne. The Specimen he gather'd there differ'd very little from the A: Calamagrostis. The Spike is much thinner set with Flowers, or more lax, the Glumes were reddish at the Points, greenish towards the Base, & hardly so much pointed as in the A: Calamagrostis. No difference was observable between the Stalks & Leaves, except in being somewhat smaller than in the A: Calamagrostis. The same was brought from Sweden by D:r Solander & given to M:r Alchorne. These Samples were uniform in their Colour, being of a yellowish brown or frillmort Colour, as if decay'd or il'dry'd. They were otherwise like M:r Alchorne's English Specimen in all Respects. These Specimens corresponded with those in Budley's Hortus siccus in the British Museum examin'd & compar'd by M:r Alchorne. Memorandum. That I search among my Specimens, & see if I have not got this very kind

species.speciesName: Poa compressa [G]. i. Cites Linn. Sp. Pl. ii. "In dry Pastures & upon Walls. May & June. This Poa varies exceedingly according to the different Stages of its Growth, & the Places where it is found, as appears from the Difference of the Samples. The Specimens mark'd, a, a, a, & c. have six or more Flowers in each Spicula. These are in the most perfect State, & are commonly found in Pastures. Those mark'd b, b, have not above three or four Flowers at most in each Spicula. These are found on Walls. Those mark'd c, c, are such as are found on Walls & are going out of Flower. All the Samples have the Stalks very much compress'd, & generally are a little bent or distorted at the Joints. These are the most certain Marks to distinguish the Species" [JL]. iii. "Poa compressa" [JL].

Poa trivialis \[TA\]. i. Cites Linn.; Ray's Syn. 409; Gmel. Fl. Sibir., vol. 1, p. 103. ii. "Common Meadow-Grass. June. This grows in Meadows & Pastures almost everywhere and is a most excellent Grass for Fodder. It varies with three, four & five Flowers in a Spicula, but are all pubescent at the Base, which is it's chief Difference (& that a very vague one) from the Poa pratensis. Compare Ray's Syn: & Gmelin's Fl. Sibir:" [JL]. iii. "Poa trivialis" [JL].

Poa compressa? These Specimens were collected in Kintbury Peat Bog, two Miles from Hungerford, Berkshire. May. The stalks were remarkably compress'd, & each Spicula consisted generally of five Flowers, but the Face & Habit of the Panicle agrees best with Ray's Description of the Gramen pratense paniculatum medium. Pag: 409. which is a Synonym of the Poa Trivialis of Lin: but that has a cylindrical Stalk
Poa compressa? in Kintbury Peat Bog

Poa pratensis \[TA\]. i\. "Mr. Hudson affirms this to be his Poa pratensis. I take it to be the same Kind which I collected in Kintbury Peat Bog. Vide" \[JL\]. ii\. "Poa pratensis, according to Hudson" \[JL\]. iii\. "P. pratensis, smooth Vagina & truncated Membrane" \[JL\].

folders.description: Folder 1\. Poa trivialis-Stipula interfoliacea. longa \[G\]. i. Cites Linn.; Ray's Syn. 409; Moris. Hist. Ox. Sect. 8, t. 5, f. 18. ii. "Great Meadow Grass. June. In Meadows & Pastures frequent. The Flowers of this are all smooth at the Base, having no kind of Pubescency; and the Leaves and Stalks are a little rough to the Touch. These are the chief Marks to distinguish it from the Poa trivialis, the number of Flowers in each Spicula being very uncertain in both Kinds; & indeed the above Characters do not seem sufficiently constant to constitute two different Species. See Gmelin: Flor: Sibiric: Vol. 1. P. 102, 103" [JL]. iii. "Poa pratensis" [JL].

Potamogeton compressum \[TA\]. i. "I rec'd this from M' Banks for the Pot: gramineum, with w'h Ray's fig. & Loesel's do very well agree, but upon comparing the larger Specimens with the fig: in the Fl. Dan: of the Pot: compressum, & seeing the Stalk to be compress'd, I am induc'd to think (if that fig: may be trusted too) it sh'd be rather the Pot: compressum, as it agrees extremely well. The Pot: gramineum in the Flor: Dan: has shorter Leaves, lanceolate, hardly linear, & a small round Stalk with a larger & longer Spike of flowers from the Summit of the Branch. It is certainly therefore the P: compressum of Fl: Dan: & I think too of Lin:" [JL]. [Specimen at top corner is P. obtusifolius.]

I never could see the Fructifications. Q: what is it—only a young var. of Poly filix mas" \[JL\]. [See also under Thelypteris oreopteris.]

"On outside of capsule:" "Polypodium Lobatum not in Fructification Yeat 'tis very Frequent to find Plants no Larger than they enclosed very much rep... [illegible] with them this grows in Plenty about W. Clough" [?]. ii. "[On inside of capsule:] "You may call this Huds: Pol: lobatum, with which it agrees, but it seems in reality to be no other than a young Plant of Pol: aculeatum Lin: from Pluk: two figures" [JL] [see Flora Scotica ed. 1, 677 (1777)]. iii. "Is this a Seedling of the Polyp: lobat: or what is it. Pray return this again if it be any Rarity for I have no other. I want to see the Lonchitis major. Polypodium Lonchitis. at Malham cove & near Litton" [JL]. iv. "These I take to be young Plants of Pol: aculeatum. from Belbank near Bingley" [JL]. [Specimen on right is P. aculeatum.]
